<rate>2< /rate><Review>Don't  be misled by the French name and pretension.  This place is all American,  right down to the ambivalent service and no frills setting.  And it is LOUD LOUD LOUD.  The hotel is at the corner of two of the busiest streets in San Francisco,  Battery and Cole,  and the windows are not high quality enough to keep out the sound.  So you will be woken up throughout the night,  probably multiple  times.  Street sweepers at 230 am,  honking cars at 4 am,  motorcycles racing at 6 am.  The staff will give you earplugs - -  but only if you ask.  When I finally asked,  they seemed completely unsurprised noise was a problem.  There are other needlessly cheap touches.  No coffee maker in the room for example.  You can get one,  but again only if you request it. And no one apparently volunteered that information to all the foreign tourists walking across the street every morning for Starbucks.< /Review><pictures>None</pictures>< Response>

< Review>

<pictures>None<//pictures><user_id>None</user_id><Response>None<//Response>< rate>

< Review>
This hotel overall feels more ‚Äúbusiness‚Äù and less ‚Äútourist‚Äù although it works for both. By Meridien standards, rooms tend toward bland and sparsely furnished, but mine was comfortable and fully functional. I appreciated the multiple outlets on the nightstand (this included a direct USB charger) as well as a Bluetooth-enabled radio. The Park Grill is the most inviting of the public spaces but curiously this restaurant is open only for breakfast and lunch. Dinner is confined to the very lively bar; this being San Francisco, it becomes a hardship only in the event rains return to California. A nice feature is a landscaped elevated walkway which extends several blocks to the Embarcadero; no need to cross streets. Light sleepers should also note that there‚Äôs a fire company around the corner; consider that source of street noise when choosing a room at check in.<//Review>

<Name>JR Curley<//Name>< date>
1503863563411<//date>
<Rating>4< /Rating>< Review>
Updated hotel thats interior doesn't match the exterior. Well located in DT SF for business travelers and tourists, it's walking distance from the Ferry Building and several large businesses. The rooms are well sized, however be aware that there aren't traditional "business" style desks in the rooms. Instead, there are high bench style desks with tall seats - making spending long hours in the room working not as comfortable as it could be. The staff are incredibly helpful, helping make sure you're comfortable and enjoying your stay. A great hotel for those staying in SF!<//Review>

Location is great for family vacationing, even though it is in the financial district.
Had a minor problem (sliding glass door to outside was off tracks, so it would not close) immediately after checking in. Night manager and staff responded quickly and fixed the problem in my suite, and also provided a room service credit for my problems.

<Text>Awesome modern, clean, with terrific views. I got a really good deal with Priceline and my check in was very late like around midnight, but went very smoothly executed by the friendly front desk staff. Very quiet, peaceful, and relaxing atmosphere, luxurious comfortable bed, with lots of pillows, and warm down comforter. Great big flat screen TV with lots of channels I woke up on a Sunday morning and found my self watching a.premier league match which I rarely have opportunity for, so greatly appreciated that. Located in the financial district, which is an an excellent location in my opinion, better and safer area, than say Mission or Civic areas. <name>Alex Katzman<//name><review>First off I never do this but I was so taken advantage of that the whole TripAdvisor and online traveler (Google) community should know about this. If you‚Äôre considering either staying or doing a conference and/or contact with this hotel, AVOID at all costs. Let me just take a second to publicly shame the management of this hotel. The Le Meridien brand should be absolutely embarrassed to have some completely inconsiderate and non-understanding employees working for them. I hope that the Marriott parent brand sees this review and takes note of how horrific an experience I had with its employees. They consistently ghosted my phone calls and refused to negotiate, or work with me during a very tough personal circumstance I had.

Let‚Äôs explain what happened.... So I had a contract for a YEAR in advance, yes that is one full year for a room block during one of the busiest weeks in San Francisco ‚Äì Oracle OpenWorld. While I had paid a small deposit, Le Meridien San Francisco then proceeded to STEAL $8,835 from me, yes again that is EIGHT THOUSAND EIGHT HUNDRED AND THIRTY FIVE DOLLARS charged to my credit card for absolutely no services rendered with ONE full year‚Äôs notice of cancellation. Now, here is why they are completely unethical and wrong for doing so‚Ä¶. Under California state law, where a consumer enters into an adhesive contract, it is unconscionable to condition that process on the consumer posting fees he or she cannot pay. Also under of California‚Äôs Consumer Legal Remedies Act, inserting an unconscionable provision in a contract is an unfair method of competition. The hotel is in violation and it is keeping my revenue and then getting revenue it will receive for the room blocks filled during those dates.

The Le Meridien San Francisco is responsible for completely bullying me out of my $8,835 and as a large corporation should be called out and ashamed. When trying to get in touch with its legal department or someone with clout on this matter I was again completely avoided and ghosted by the hotel after calling numerous times ‚Äì it‚Äôs funny how then when I called under another pretense saying I needed to book a venue and/or room block they picked up right away.

Never again should anyone reading this or anyone that enters into a contract with this hotel suffer the same kind of abuse that I went through. The Hotel staff, General manager, Marriott, Le Meridien if you are reading this please consider contacting me and making me whole for this matter or I will be forced to reconsider all of my options and how to proceed from here‚Ä¶. Travelers there are so many other nice neighboring hotels I'd highly recommend staying there and avoid this property.<//review>< user_id>

<user_id>113592876760564751938<//user_id>< Name>
J M< /Name>
<Time>1493661471598</Time>< rating>
4< /rating>
< review>
Really loved staying at this hotel. I loved the way it was decorated. It is very modern and tasteful. Great room, spacious, clean. Had a great view with a sliding door that only budged a little but I understand that is for safety reasons. The customer service was above average, everyone was extremely nice and helpful. Great bar, everything is very clean. The reason I gave it a 4 instead of a 5. This was my first time staying at this hotel and my first time in San Francisco. Finding the hotel was easy but figuring out where to go for parking was very frustrating. The only parking available at the hotel was thru valet which cost $62 a night. There was a parking garage down the street, which was around $32 a night. Obviously if you used the parking garage, you would have to walk the street with your luggage and who knows where you would have parked in the garage. We choose to do the valet parking. When I called to confirm my reservations a few weeks prior, it just would have been nice to know the parking situations and have a heads up prior to going and finding out.</review>

Le Meridien is in San Francisco's Financial District and close to the Ferry Building, North Beach, Jackson Square, Chinatown, and buses to Marin County and Berkeley. Rooms are recently updated and look like the stock photos that are shown online. Staff is nice and efficient. Rooms can be expensive depending on when you're visiting but are worth it.< /Review>

<gmap_id>0x8085806033e06771:0x5585cb03086b5f0f</gmap_id><Resp>None<//Resp><UserId.>None</UserId.>< Review>
I have been an SPG member for over 10 years and have rotated between Gold and Platinum status. I live in the Bay Area and have stayed at Le Meridien in the Embarcadero many times for weekend getaways with my wife. I made a reservation online through SPG. All seemed OK until we arrived and saw that the entire lobby ground floor and restaurant was closed for construction. We had to enter a service elevator and go up to the second floor where we checked into a temporary lobby area. We did get upgraded to a very nice top floor room. When I made the reservation there was no mention of the renovation nor the issue with the lobby and restaurant. I'm not sure how long the construction will last, but I recommend anyone check with the hotel if having a nice lobby and place to eat and relax on site is important to your stay.<//Review>

<username>Brooke Young< /username><response>None<//response><rating>4</rating><time>1498164214526<//time>< gmapID>
0x8085806033e06771:0x5585cb03086b5f0f<//gmapID>
< review>
Le Meridien is a good choice centrally located near the Embarcadero Center. The hotel is focused primarily on business travelers and provides all the necessary staples: a good restaurant serving a breakfast and lunch and a fairly good bar scene.  The bar presents a respectable menu (the burger was above average) and some good locals beers.  It could benefit from staying open a little later than the 11:30 closing.  The gym is above average with multiple fitness machines and some free weights.  This would benefit from a upgrade in free weights, though there may not be enough space.  Rooms are spacious and clean and the staff is pleasant and professional.  All in all, this is a good bet for business travel.<//review>
< userid>
116207068243120788912</userid>
< Pics>
None</Pics>
</record>
</dataset><record>
< Time>
1546896255408<//Time>
< user_id>
104395967784577179550< /user_id>
<rating>3<//rating>< Pictures>
None<//Pictures>
< Text>
usually sleep around on my hotel choices when in SF, finding the right mix of location, price, and comfort. This time required some extra space, as I wanted to host some local friends for a small New Year's Eve gathering.

Upon arrival, as a Platinum Elite Marriott member, I was upgraded to a Hospitality Suite, which sounded great but wasn't much of an upgrade in my opinion. While it was larger than the suite we booked, the sleeping area was open to the living room, view was not great, and there was no balcony. After a quick call down, we were set up in our Bay-facing balcony suite. We loved the separate room with a door, floor-to-ceiling windows, great view of the Bay Bridge from both balcony and beautiful bathroom window.

This is not a 5* property, so expectations were set accordingly. While the room itself gets solid marks, it was showing some wear in places, especially in carpeting and drapery. Service was a mixed bag. On a positive note, the front desk allowed me return unused breakfast vouchers, giving me Marriott Rewards points instead. I wish Marriott would give this as a credit to be used in any way (e.g., room service), but I digress. Some of the less desirable service interactions included a room service rep hanging up on me (to be fair, it was right before the 11am breakfast deadline.....but still); not receiving requested items on two occasions (plate set and cutlery); and just a general tone of inconvenience when calling to request anything. In-person interactions we much more pleasant -- front desk, bellmen, doorman (set up during New Year's Eve asking for key cards, which was much appreciated).

I'd stay here again if the price is right and am in need of a larger suite (hard to come by in SF...shock!), but with all the choices in and around SF, this may end up being a one-off.

Pro Tip: Eggs Benedict and Corn Flakes French Toast from room service....you won't be sorry!< /Text>

<user_id>108984393085255111603</user_id><pictures>None<//pictures><Rate>5< /Rate><Response>None</Response>< username>
Stephen Vargo<//username>
< Text>
We were a bit worried about staying at this property since reviews on this site and others mentioned problems. What got our attention the most was the reported poor customer service and lack of recognition of Starwood Preferred Guest status.

LET ME TELL YOU, WE HAD NONE OF THESE ISSUES!!

We were greeted cordially at checkin and our Starwood status was recognized and rewarded with an upgrade to a corner room with a balcony that was awesome, facing the bay! From every moment we encountered a staff member, we were treated like valued customers. I don't know if the hotel recently did training on this, but it seemed to be throughout the hotel that every member greeted us and asked if there was anything they could do to make it better.

However, there were challenges that were met with wonderful reactions and offers to compensate. For example, it seemed at one point (totally by our misunderstanding) that someone (employee) had entered the room without permission. The hotel's security took this VERY seriously and checked every logged entry into the room via the electronic key system at our door. They provided a detailed record of every entry since we had checked in. We then figured out our error, but the hotel STILL offered to move us to another room. They never downplayed our fears (which sounded crazy, but were merely mistaken).

My wife ordered room service that wasn't quite right (a food allergy/sensitivity issue). When she called to report it, they took the charge off of our room and sent a proper replacement. When we asked about not having a coffee maker in the room (not a standard feature), they brought one immediately. Further, due to these issues, they gave us a very generous bump in our SPG points.

Overall, I would say that the hotel has excellent customer service and perhaps has made some big changes, we did not see ANY of the "negative" issues reported previously.

We would gladly stay here again!< /Text>

<rating>None</rating>< text>
I arrived at this hotel after a long international flight on points and requested an early check in as I was leaving 5am the following day for another flight.I arrived at the hotel at 8AM and the room was not ready, which I understand. The front desk staff said, we have rooms available but those are for higher priority guests where we have contracts to honor their requests. Granted I am only SPG gold, I thought that was comment was not professional and not what I wanted to hear after 12 hours of travel. I feel asleep in the lobby and two hours later- a room was available. Great!

I got to my room and after writing some emails and I went to take a nap. I got in my the bed and there was a used condom on the side of the bed. Gross! I called the front desk and they seemed non empathetic about the situation. They said they would send housekeeping up but I requested a new room (which they honored, but did not seem friendly about it) The new room was fine, but was lacking a bath robe. When I called to ask for one, they informed me they ran out of all bath robes. Again, not too big a deal, just expected more from this type of hotel.

I have concerns about the hygiene and cleanliness of the hotel rooms. I am also surprised that no one followed up to check to see the new room was OK or apologize for the getting in bed with a used condom. Poor service and cleaninless will make me or want to visit this hotel again. Should have spent my rewards points on the Sheraton or Westin.<//text>

This place has all of the hi-tech connectivity options with exception for the chords.  The hotel staff won't provide them either which makes most of the fancy connectivity options useless.

</record></dataset><record>
< review>
We didn't mind that the hotel was under construction/renovation, although it would have been nice to know that beforehand via the website or an email. It's unacceptable to not provide a coffeemaker of some sort in the room, and then offer horrible-tasting (weak) coffee at the front desk. Do you really want the majority of your guest slogging down in various states of dress and hangover, etc. to your public areas for a tiny cup of coffee? Also, the hotel accidentally charged us a nightly rate even though we booked on points. They cleared it up immediately and credited our card, but we left with the feeling that this happens quite a lot. We hope the hotel improves after its upgrade, but wouldn't recommend it at all presently.</review>

< review>
Stayed here in late 2015. The check-in seemed a little clumsy but may have been due to the holidays - long lines, just a few people at the counter to handle.

The hotel is modern and well-kept and we were treated to a nice view of San Francisco with a balcony and living room. Don't forget about the little perks that Le Meridien provides - a free coffee voucher at their coffee bar and free admission to museums in the area. Would definitely stay here again, especially for the modern design and style of the Le Meridien theme.</review>

Ken67< /user_name>
<review>After numerous flight delays because of weather, I arrived at this hotel at 3 am, dead tired, having now been up for about 24 hours. When I went to my room, I opened the door and found the lights on and wet towels on the floor. I immediately thought that someone must be in the room. I went back downstairs and reported this and was told that housekeeping sometimes forgets to pick up the towels (really???). One of the staff members then went upstairs to check it out. He came back in a few minutes and had a long whispered conversation with the night clerk. I was then told that this room wasn't available and there were no more rooms. (My reservation was made as part of a group booking, so I assume it should have been a safe reservation.)

You can imagine how I felt hearing that there was no room at the inn. However, the night manager spent some time looking through the computer and came up with another room. I was escorted upstairs by a hotel staff member, and when I asked about a room key, I was told that it would be slipped under the door later that night. Very strange.

I was attending a two-day meeting hosted by a local company, who told all of us that they left gift bags at the hotel for each of us. Since there was no gift bag, I later asked at the front desk about this and was told that they would check. I never heard anything, so later I asked again. I then received a message that the host company did not leave enough gift bags, a fact that they deny. Where did it go? Was it taken by the person who took my reserved room?

Did the hotel give away my room to someone else? Did the hotel charge both me and this other person for the same room?

After spending all day at a meeting, I came back to my room to find some cheese, fruit and crackers, a bottle of wine and a note of apology for the misunderstanding on check-in. While I recognize this as a decent gesture, the food was dried out from sitting there all day, and I wasn't going to have a chance to drink the wine.

More appropriate, in my mind, was to make some kind of financial adjustment to my bill. However, because I was seldom in the room and had to leave on an early flight, I never really had time to discuss this.

The whole experience seemed wholly inappropriate for a hotel which portends to be a first-class property.< /review><resp>None<//resp>< Pictures>
None< /Pictures>
</record>

< user>
117454334615218647597<//user>
< Review>
Pros: modern design, close to tourist attractions, fantastic views from the room, clean/well kept rooms, helpful staff, there's a Safeway within walking distance if you need groceries.

Cons: valet is $60/day, noisy at times from all the street traffic, no free wifi

Tip: you can park in the parking garage across the street for $33/day. There's a breakfast spot within a 5min walk that has awesome breakfast sandwiches called Cafe Me.

Me and my family enjoyed our stay at this hotel during a 5-day vacation in San Francisco. We look forward to coming back soon!</Review>

< Text>
This was a shocking experience. I am a Starwoods reward member for 13 years and have stayed in SPG hotels all over the world.
We arrived mid morning and were able to check in earlier, great. We checking into the room and the small sliding glass door had cigarette butts thrown all around the small opening crack. I brought this to the attention of the house cleaner who said she would clean it up, but seriously, how is that not taken care of immediately.
When we returned to the room mid afternoon, our heads were rattling form the jack hammer construction a floor or 2 above. I called immediately front desk and was told I would have room changed. I asked to have the duty manager come up to the room to experience this terrible noise. The manager that came up to the room was also shown the filth all over the hallway carpeting from construction on a room 3 doors down. She said it was not her responsibility but would make sure this was brought to the attention of the proper manager. When I asked how a guest could make a reservation and be checked in and not told about possible renovation problems, she said she was sorry.
We were moved up to the 18th floor, which was away from the noise and a newly renovated room, which we appreciated. But this is no way to communicate with guests.
Ken Green</Text>

<name>Icebrgus< /name><time>1363996800000<//time><Rating>None<//Rating><text>It all comes down to the experience and my last moments here tainted the entire stay. All along the staff was very accommodating, friendly and met my every need. I had even forgotten an iPhone charger and as they had several on hand, let me borrow it for the duration of my stay . Since I had to return it I decided to check out at the front desk and get a final folio from there. He was on the phone when I arrived so I waited patiently for him to be done. When I handed the iPhone charger and thanked them for letting me use it he said (with an attitude) "Oh, so that is where it has been." Then when I asked to check out he asked me if I got a copy of the folio in my room. I said yes, and before I could finish he said that is all you need. I said no, my company prefers a final bill not an estimated bill of final charges. He was starting to get on my nerves and seemed to refuse my request twice. It was 5AM and it was not like the place was busy and he had a lot to handle at the time. He finally complied with my request and did not thank me for staying. < Text>
I originally booked a hotel at the Hyatt Fisherman's Wharf for a few days, but the first night was overbooked. As a result, we were sent to Le Meridian free of charge. The Le Meridian was supposed to direct bill to the Hyatt, but they did not. It was only till I returned to Los Angeles that I discovered not just one charge, but two charges to my account.

The first charge was supposed to be direct billed to the Hyatt. After several calls and speaking to multiple people, the charge was supposed to be resolved. I later check my card, and I was charged again! Two charges! The front desk manager stated she accidentally charged me again and voided it immediately, which fell off after a few days. 

The second charge that went through was due to mistaken identity. They charged me due to another guest having the same name. How is it possible that they got the room number and/or credit card number wrong and just went off my name? 

All in all, I've been promised several refunds and have yet to see anything. It's been a nightmare calling every day to sort out some new mistake from the Le Meridian. I definitely would not stay here, even if it was free again.< /Text>

<Name>LadyGator<//Name>< date>
1484611200000</date>
<Rate>None< /Rate><Review>As I write this, I am still in shock as to what just transpired. I am staying for 3 days/2 nights and signed up for green choice. My husband and I arrived yesterday to 2 bottles of water, which we consumed. So at the end of a long day today we realized we were out of water so I dialed zero and asked for 4 bottles since we drink quite a bit of water. To my surprise, I was told that they can only send me 2 bottles because I was only entitled to just that number per day to which I replied that we wanted 4 bottles. Having NEVER had any issues at any Starwood around the WORLD, and as a LONGSTANDING PLATINUM guest, I thought nothing of it. I was again told that only 2 bottles could be sent. When I questioned it I was then told I'd have to pay for the other 2 bottles. I asked him to identify himself which he promptly did. Imagine how puzzled and confused I was in light of the fact that we' d be there the following day until 4:00 pm ( mind you it was already 11:00 pm). So I told this individual that it made no sense that I would not pay for 2 more bottles when I was a platinum guest and would be there through the following day. I also added that no matter what and whether they ended up charging or not we wanted 4 bottles of water. So he then reluctantly said that he would send them up to our room. He sounded exasperated with my insistence to get 4 bottles and he abruptly hung up. 2 mns later a knock on the door and 2 bottles are delivered. So I asked the delivery guy about the other two then he said " they only gave me 2" and said " Sorry you can only get two"!!! I must admit that I thought I was in the twilight zone and questioned him again about the missing 2 bottles. To which he said (as he was walking away) "no, no, I'm sorry you can only have 2. You're going to have to call for the other 2".....
I could not understand that these guys decided to ration my water request even if charging them to my room was ultimately their option. 
They then called and the purported night "manager", a woman who shall remain nameless and frankly deserves no mention, spoke to my husband and I could hear her telling him rather loudly, and combatively that he could not have another 2 bottles. She sounded upset that we challenged the delivery guy and reiterated arrogantly that 2 bottles were all we were getting. My husband reiterated our request and she then rather annoyingly and sternly stated that they would be sent but "you're going to have to pay for it". 
I totally lost my cool and headed downstairs in my PJs to question why I did not get what I asked for whether or not they planned to charge me and why this seemingly incompetent neophyte was pushing back on 2 bottles of water in a way that truly bordered disrespect or at least a lack of awareness. I was triggered and freely let it be known. I was loud, upset and made it clear I was incensed and did not care to entertain the lip service. As a paying customer I asked for 4 bottles and my expectations were that they sent me 4 bottles. The charges I would deal with on the back end. The night manager (the rudest and most CLUELESS, IRREVERENT, ARROGANT, and ALOOF woman I have met in a while) and a few unidentified guys all surreptitiously showed up as if they were all dispatched to save the day and perhaps display a show of force or unity in ineptitude. I make no bones about the fact that I was loud and equally irreverent at that stage. I reiterated my position, albeit rather loudly and sternly, that all I wanted were 4 bottles of water, that it was none of their business to question me especially after expressing their desire to charge me. 
So I asked that clueless woman manager to help me understand the logic of charging me when I had not had my 2 bottles today and in one hour (at midnight) I would theoretically be due another 2 bottles. So she said "well if that's what you want to do then do that". I then let her know that made no sense to entertain that option when she was refusing any logic associated with just letting me have 2 extra bottles practically 40 mns before to which she retorted "so does this make any sense to you?" with a defiant and tone-deaf manner that just truly irritated me. So I asked again " what happens if I don't ask for 2 bottles tomorrow? Do I then get a credit for the charges?" She then said "no, you'll get charged for 2 bottles and that's that. There won't be a credit". I then told her that her boss would hear from me about this mess and she slyly said "I already emailed him"...
I can't begin to express the swell of frustration and disbelief that overcame me for standing in the lobby after 11:00 pm arguing about 2 bottles of water that I was asking to get to my room. 2 bottles of water because we wanted to remain hydrated through the night!!!!! Just unbelievable!.......What was it to them and why this arrogance? While holding her defiant stare I firmly told her that I wanted my additional 2 bottles and promptly dismissed any additional retort from her. She just said " fine I'll send you the water and charge you". As I walked away I could hear them laughing and commenting about the incident. 
We waited about 15 mns and no deliveries came. My husband followed me down in the lobby got the succeeding Supervisor, a gentleman who swiftly said he would send the 2 bottles without skipping a beat and even thinking twice about it. 
In the meantime the outgoing crew led by this woman manager tried to be slick and sent up 2 glass bottles of water as opposed to the (plastic) Nestle ones that are stocked in the room. They charged us $14.00+ for those glass bottles. Unfortunately for her the delivery that the gentleman evening Manager promised came up right after Ashe had promised. We simply returned the glass bottles for refund and kept the 2 Nestle bottles. I have a feeling that the woman who befuddly carries the manager title, did not realize that her successor followed through as intended and as was originally expected. His easy going nature and quick agreement to accommodate was a stark contrast and exactly what one would expect. Kudos to him for doing what was right!!!! 
Never have I experienced such ineptitude and lack of connection to purpose on the account of a supposed management team. I would not have that woman manager as a trainee at a neighborhood store or a fruit concession stand let alone a prestigious Starwood hotel in San Francisco. She is not deserving of that title and completely missed the point. I am a LOYAL customer and I simply asked for 4 bottles of water. Your job is to send them to me and decide on what your policy states. If it is charging then do that and let me then deal with it on the back end. It is not for you to challenge my request and display your sarcasm and ignorance at me. It does not bode well for you or your property as I am completely rigid about customer service that is tactful, courteous, and adaptable. I pushed right back and I am sure it was unexpected. It goes without saying that I have no desire to go back there during my next visit in a few weeks. I am sure they have their filter about my intervention but I will not apologize for standing up for what I have come to know as the staple STELLAR, unequivocal, unquestionable service from Starwood. 
So with the power of "the pen" I am warning others that you need to be cognizant of the fact that your voice as a customer may not carry far at that hotel with this woman's stiff view of her beloved and golden policies. Your voice will not matter to her and some others at this property. Through her cluelessness Le Meridien San Francisco missed the mark and I will surely take my money and loyalty elsewhere....in the end the correct thing prevailed. The succeeding Manager's prompt recovery allowed us to have the extra bottles and, just like I promised this lady it would happen, I paid nothing (zilch) for the water. This is truly a stinging case of the customer is always right but unfortunately I will never again set foot at that place!!!!.... The liberating power of bountiful choices in sister properties all around frankly renders this manager-in-training and this facility irrelevant in my eyes...< /Review><Pics>None<//Pics>< response>
None<//response>

0x8085806033e06771:0x5585cb03086b5f0f<//GmapID>
< Text>
This is as much a complaint about Starwood as it is Le Meridien. I called twice, weeks in advance of our trip, to inquire about the airport shuttle offered on their website. The original call was to Starwood and then I decided to make a separate call straight to the front desk just to be sure. On both calls I was told that all I needed to do was to call the number provided on the website any time after finishing at baggage claim at SFO and a shuttle would be sent. However, when I called the number at 1:00am from SFO, it reported that the number was no longer in service. So I called the front desk from the baggage claim. NOW they tell me that the hotel does not have a shuttle service. I'm supposed to reserve a shuttle with one of the two companies they suggest. Then they give me a web page address for one of the shuttle companies. The web page is for making reservations, NOT for being picked up immediately. So I call the Starwoods number and they look it up and then attempt to provide me the same number from the web page that is "no longer in service". Long story short, it eventually gets sorted out that the number on the website is only open during business hours (but it still a 3rd party service). In the end I had to talk one of the shuttle drivers at the airport into giving me and the wife a ride to the hotel at 1:45am without a reservation with no help from Starwood or the hotel desk.

Also, I was told when I was making the reservation that if I joined up to become a Starwood Preferred" member (for free) that the internet fees at the hotel would be waived. I asked the front desk for the access code and they tell me that only PLATINUM members could receive the waived internet fees. So I'm back on the phone with Starwood at 2:30am asking them what the deal is. Turns out that I made the mistake of actually calling and talking to a live person at Starwood when making my reservation. The internet fees are only waived if reservations had been done online and since I've already checked into the hotel there's "nothing they can do". So I'm paying $45 just to be able to write this review when I was told my internet access would be free.

Finally, the hotel itself is a lot smaller overall than expected based on the pictures provided online. The hallway has a funky smell to it (thankfully the room does not). The walls are pretty thin though. We're on the 5th floor and can hear the street sweepers going by loud enough that it woke my wife up to ask what the noise was.

All in all, I'll do my best to avoid any and all Starwood properties in the future after this first experience with them.<//Text>

<user_name>QBRG</user_name><Time>1359936000000< /Time>< rate>

<Text>From a confusing temporary lobby layout to a hole in the bedding, this hotel is an overpriced two-star lodge. The place tries to convey style, but it is not even skin deep. The toilet in the bathroom of the room we occupied was loud, but failed to properly flush. The sink would not properly drain. The tub is so slippery that I am surprised any decent facility would take this risk of a guest slipping and falling while taking a shower. Getting a wake-up call an hour earlier than requested is not a sign of good service. < Date>
1388636036583</Date>

None</response>
<Review>What's in a name?

This review is my opinion of Le Meridien San Francisco, based on our stay there.  Having stayed at Le Meridien in Budapest earlier this year, we expected a similar experience here in San Francisco, but we were disappointed. The front-end staff, including the valet, are less professional, evidenced by both their  demeanor and appearance. They appear to be trained to a lower standard than their European counterparts.

We attempted to check in slightly after 3pm, the advertised check-in time, but neither of our two rooms were ready.  Consequently, one room was "upgraded" to include a view and I was asked to leave my mobile number so that the staff could call me when the other room was ready, which was to be by 3:30pm. Of course, the call never came so I ended up having to go back to the front desk and wait in line to see the clerk to inquire about the other room, which by that time was ready. I was told that the reason I was not called was because "things got busy."

The rooms are okay, though the walls let sound through so you can actually make out entire conversations your neighbors are having.  Some street noise makes its way in, even up to the 17th floor, but only the sirens are annoying. The Nakamichi CD player is a nice touch (it has an auxiliary input so you can plug in your player with a 1/4" plug). No refills on the small soap bars, shampoo, or plastic cups were provided throughout our stay, so bring your own. Our room had the banner that hangs on and describes the complimentary bottle of water, but no bottled water was ever present.

Had it not been for the fact that we were celebrating the recent marriage of my sister (one half of the other couple that was traveling with us), we would have checked into another place, where we feel more value could have been gotten for our hard-earned money.

Valet parking was a little over $60 a night. That seemed high to its. The valet directed us to park around the corner at a public parking, where we paid $32 a night.

Update: Although we never did get soap or plastic cup refills, we did finally get a complimentary water bottle in the room, on the third day. We stayed a total of four nights.</Review><Pics>None</Pics>< name>
Gal Ret</name>
